intro: Spraguea pulchella, commonly known as the showy spraguea, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking, showy flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in wetlands and swampy areas, where it thrives in moist, acidic soils. Its leaves are opposite and lance-shaped, while its flowers are usually pink or red with prominent white veins. Spraguea pulchella is often found in marshes and along the edges of ponds, where it plays a role in wetland ecosystems.
